qas.question: What ideas are used to understand groups beyond symbols?
What has to be compatible with the group operation?
What concept describes groups that can be related to each other via functions?
What is needed to understand structural concepts?
Both groups and sets have what?
What function is used to break groups into pieces?
Groups do not need to respect structures in what sense?
What is an example of a subgroup?

context: To understand groups beyond the level of mere <b3_0>symbolic manipulations<b3_0/> as above, more <a0_0>structural concepts<a0_0/> have to be employed.c[›] There is a conceptual principle underlying all of the following notions: to take advantage of the <b4_0>structure<b4_0/> offered by groups (which sets, being "structureless", do not have), <a1_0>constructions related to groups<a1_0/> have to be compatible with the group operation. This compatibility manifests itself in the following notions in various ways. For example, groups can be related to each other via functions called <a2_0><b5_0>group homomorphisms<b5_0/><a2_0/>. By the mentioned principle, they are required to respect the group structures in a <b6_0>precise<b6_0/> sense. The structure of groups can also be understood by breaking them into pieces called subgroups and <b7_0>quotient groups<b7_0/>. The principle of "preserving structures"—a recurring topic in mathematics throughout—is an instance of working in a category, in this case the category of groups.
